turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I lost you.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I never knew you, Dad.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Fire.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: On the job?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: It was an abandoned warehouse - hit by lightening.  Butch told Ma it was just one wrong turn. Said it wasn't your fault.  You went with the training, with your instincts.  If you'd just gone left instead of right, you would've made it.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: That can't be...that's not gonna happen.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: It did, Pop.  It did.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: October 12, 1969.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: But that's tomorrow.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Tomorrow.  Jesus...it hasn't happened. It doesn't have to happen.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Don't go.  Don't go in that warehouse...

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I don't understand.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Dad...?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Chief?!  Is that you?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah, it's me.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You're the voice of an angel, Johnny.  If you hadn't told me, no way I would'a ever made it.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Dad, you there?  You okay?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yeah.  I'm okay.  What about you?  I want to know.  About you.  And your mom.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: We're doing all right, Dad.  We're doing good.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Tell me.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: It's hard to explain.  Something happened today.  It was like a dream.  And when I woke up I had all these new memories. Good times.  Times we never had before.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I'm glad.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Dad, I gotta tell you this...cause you should know.  Cause I still remember.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What, Johnny?  What is it?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: What it was like when you died in the fire...

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Right here, Chief.  Sorry I lost you last night.  Damn thing keeps cutting out.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Dad...Dad... There's... I need to...

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Are you alright"?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Something happened, something...

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What?  Johnny, what's wrong?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: It's Mom.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What?  What is it?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: She's not here.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Whatta you mean she's not here?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: She...she died.  It's like it just happened.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: She just died, your mother just died?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: No Dad, it happened a long time ago, a long time ago for me.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: October 22, 1969.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Jesus Christ...that's...ten days from now.  How?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Murdered?  Why?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: There was this case.  A serial.  He murdered three women, all nurses, between '68 and '69.  The papers called them the Nightingale Murders.  They never caught him.  But the killings just stopped.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What kinda twisted animal.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Dad, we did something.  Something to make it worse.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Whatta you mean...

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: He didn't just kill three women anymore. He killed ten.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Something we did changed the case...changed history.  Mom wasn't dead.  But then after you didn't die in the fire something must have happened.  And this guy, this Nightingale guy, he kept on killing...it was like a spree...seven more women.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I gotta take her away, John.  I'm gonna take your mother away.  He can't hurt her if I take her away.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I don't know...  What about the other women?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I'll warn them.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: That'll never work.  They'll just think you're crazy.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What can we do?  You don't even know who this guy is.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: No.  Nobody got...  Wait a minute.  I might not know who he is, but I know where he's gonna be.  I got the case file.  We know what he's gonna do before he does it.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: So what should I do?  Call the police? You think they'll believe me?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: They will if they catch him in the act. You can make that happen, Dad.  You can tail the victim and call it in at just the right moment.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I don't know, John.  I'm a fire fighter. This is...this is different.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I do know.  I'm a cop.  This is what I do.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You ever talk to a victim's family?  The one's left behind?  They don't act like what you'd think.  There's panic and fear.  But mostly, it's like there's this logic problem.  And if they could only solve it, everything would be okay.  But if you look real close - look at their eyes - you can see it.  Just a glimmer.  But somewhere they know.  They know their world is never gonna be the same.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What if the radio stops working?  Christ, what if I can't reach you again?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Then you get Mom the hell out.  But Dad, those other women weren't supposed to die.  We don't try to stop this guy, we're gonna live with that for the rest of our lives.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Why not just get the cops to watch the bar?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: They'll question her.  Whatever they tell her could change what happens.  No, I want you to follow her.  See if anybody's watching her, hittin' on her. I'm betting somebody's gonna walk outta that bar with her.  When they do, you call the cops.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What do I tell them?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Tell 'em there's a homicide in progress... cause by the time they show up there will be.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I'll be damned.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Did you see him?  Do you know who he is?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: No.  I just kept talking to her.  There was a lot of guys in that bar - could'a been any of 'em.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: It's okay.  This is working.  This is gonna work.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Whatta we do now?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Sissy Clark, 190 Riverside Dr., apartment 3C.  Tomorrow.  She's a nursing student.  Paying her way as a cocktail waitress at the Peppermint Lounge, on west 63rd.  Left work at two A M...killed in her apartment, between two thirty and five.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Got it.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Dad, I think I may be able to get you enough information to make sure the DA can nail this bastard.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Coupla days ago they dug up a body in Washington Heights - Mary Finelli.  Girl disappeared in '68.  Turns out she was his first kill.  Which means he probably knew her.  Most serials know their first victim.  I'm gonna do some checking - see if I can put any of this together...

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: All right, I'm with you.  I just hope we know what the hell we're doing.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Tell me something good, Chief.  Tell me about the future.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Well they found out cigarettes give you lung cancer.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What else, John.  It must be different, huh?  Are people living on the moon?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Didn't happen, we got enough problems down here.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What are we like in...1998?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: We're okay...we're good, Dad.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Hey, what about the Amazin's?  They pull it off?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You really wanna know?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yeah, you betcha.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Well, game five was the big one.  It turned in the bottom of the 6th.  We were down 3-0.  Cleon Jones gets hit on the foot - left a scuff mark on the ball. Clendenon comes up.  The count goes to 2 2.  High fastball.  He nailed it.  Weis slammed a solo shot in the 7th to tie. Jones and Swoboda scored in the 8th.  We won, Pop.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Wow.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Hang on a sec, John.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You there?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: John, say hello to my wife...Julia.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: H-hi.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: John, you still there?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I'm right here, Dad.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You all right?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah, I think so...

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Don't worry, Chief.  I'm not gonna let anything happen to her...no matter what.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: He killed her John.  He killed her and I didn't do a thing to stop it.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: It's not your fault, Dad.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yes it is...we did this.  We changed everything.  I've been having bad dreams, Johnny. Dreams where I die...in the fire.  I was supposed to die in that warehouse.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: This is wrong...it's like we cheated...

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I know...  But Dad, you can't go back.  You didn't die in that fire.  And no matter what you do, nothing is gonna change that.  So all we can do is deal with this...and try to make it right.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I don't think I can.  I'm not a cop.  I can't.   I can't stop this guy.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: But we can, we can do it together. Spirit and guts, remember?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Johnny, I know, but...

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I need you to believe in me.  To believe that we can do this.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: John, he's got my driver's license.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: He took my driver's license, John, he knows where we live.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: He took your wallet?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: No, he tossed the wallet, but he kept the license.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: He touched your wallet!  Where's your wallet?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: In my pocket.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: We got him!  Dad you got him!

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: His prints.  You've got his prints.  I'll run them through criminal index.  You gotta get me that wallet.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: How the hell am I gonna do that?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Listen to me, very carefully, take your wallet out, just touch it on the corners.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What...

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Please, Dad, just do it.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Okay, okay...

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I got it.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Right, now I need you to tape it up on the outside, where he touched it, so the prints keep.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: It's gonna work, Dad.  We're gonna stop him.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Hang on.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You're telling me this maniac is a cop? What the hell am I supposed to do with that one?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Call the FBI.  Use a pay phone.  Don't give 'em your name, Dad.  Just tell 'em that it was Shepard who killed Finelli and Clark and the others.  That he's the Nightingale.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What are you doing here, Satch?  You off today?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Dad, you there?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Dad, what the hell is going on?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Just a minute, John...okay?  Don't go away.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: John, you there?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah, Dad.  What the hell is going on?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Satch is busting me for Sissy Clark's murder.  John...

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I'm here, Dad.  I'm here.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We did it, John.  We stopped him.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Wait.  Something's wrong.  I don't...

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What's wrong?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I don't remember.  Why don't I remember?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I'm not your uncle, kid.  Gordo, what are you doing here?

turns.speaker: GORDO
turns.text: Sully!  Is that you?

turns.speaker: GORDO
turns.text: Hey, Sull.  My cable's out again.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: What the hell is that smell?

turns.speaker: GORDO
turns.text: Hey, OK if Gordy uses your old gear?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I think it's somewhere in the closet... if you can find it.

turns.speaker: GORDO
turns.text: Sull!  What the hell!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I talked to him Gordo.  I talked to my Dad.

turns.speaker: GORDO
turns.text: C'mon, man.  Get inside.  I'll come over. We'll play some Nintendo.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: No.  I gotta tell him the address, so he doesn't go in.

turns.speaker: GORDO
turns.text: Go in where?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: The warehouse.  Buxton seeds.  It's tomorrow.

turns.speaker: GORDO
turns.text: I know pal.  I remember.  Twenty-nine years tomorrow.

turns.speaker: GORDO
turns.text: How you feeling?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Better.

turns.speaker: GORDO
turns.text: John.  John, you all right?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Longbranch...?

turns.speaker: GORDO
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: My father didn't die in a fire?

turns.speaker: GORDO
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: My father didn't die in a fire?

turns.speaker: GORDO
turns.text: Fire?  What are you talking about?  He had cancer, John.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Cancer.  It was the cigarettes.  Right? The cigarettes?

turns.speaker: GORDO
turns.text: Yeah, lung cancer.  Ten years ago.

turns.speaker: GORDO
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: The Ham radio.  That's how come he didn't die in the fire.

turns.speaker: GORDO
turns.text: This is the Space Cowboy.  I'm an intergalactic traveler from the Federation planet earth.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Gordo?

turns.speaker: GORDO
turns.text: How'd you know my name, mister?

turns.speaker: GORDO
turns.text: I better give you my address then.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Oh don't worry kid, I know where you live.  Now I want you to go upstairs and write this down, buy Yahoo. You got that Space Cowboy.  Y-a-h-o-o. It's a magic word and I never want you to forget it.

turns.speaker: GORDO
turns.text: You got a deal, mister.  I mean Santa.

turns.speaker: SATCH
turns.text: Don't choke on your pride, Sull.  You ain't ever gonna catch another one like that.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: She made up her mind.  Nothin' I do is gonna change it.

turns.speaker: SATCH
turns.text: Nothing you're willing to do.

turns.speaker: SATCH
turns.text: You're not looking too good.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Whoa, I just...I just...

turns.speaker: SATCH
turns.text: Maybe you outta lay off a little...

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Gordo, I wasn't dreaming.  I talked to him, it was real.

turns.speaker: SATCH
turns.text: Another rough night, huh?  That it?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah.  That's it.

turns.speaker: SATCH
turns.text: This is getting real old, John.  And I'm tired up to here with it...

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I'm sorry.  I just...you know...I...

turns.speaker: SATCH
turns.text: And I'm tired of the I'm sorrys.  I don't need 'em.  What I need is a partner I can count on.  I care about you.  Not cause of me and your old man.  Not cause of your mom. But because of you.

turns.speaker: SATCH
turns.text: She makes ten.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Ten?  No.  I remember this case.  Three. He killed three women.

turns.speaker: SATCH
turns.text: What're you talking'?  You know better than anybody, John.  You've read this file a thousand times.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: That's what we need here, Satch.  A lucky break.

turns.speaker: SATCH
turns.text: That wasn't luck, Johnny boy.  That was smarts and ten plus on the job.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Our lucky break.  Mario ID'd the dental. Mary Finelli...reported missing April 16, 1968.

turns.speaker: SATCH
turns.text: April 16...?  That means she was the first.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Which means he probably knew her.

turns.speaker: SATCH
turns.text: This case just got hot.  We pull on this string...

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Okay, lemme walk you through it.

turns.speaker: SATCH
turns.text: Mind if I shake it off first...so's I can concentrate better.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I ran him through BCI...got a hit. Busted for sexual assault: March 22, 1970.  Eight days after the last Nightingale murder.

turns.speaker: SATCH
turns.text: So you figure the murders stop 'cause he's off the street.  Then by the time he gets paroled, he's smartened up enough to control himself?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Not the first time that's been true.  I'm telling you, I got a feeling about this guy.  This is the guy, Satch.

turns.speaker: SATCH
turns.text: Uh, huh.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SATCH
turns.text: I'm just trying to figure what interests me more: the possibility that Daryl is the guy, or you making him absolutely the guy.

turns.speaker: SATCH
turns.text: Got a minute?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah.  Sure.

turns.speaker: SATCH
turns.text: He ain't our guy, John.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Just cause he didn't want to look at the photos doesn't mean he isn't the doer. Not everyone fits the profile.

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: Hi, this is Julia.  Please leave a message after the tone.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Hey, Ma, it's me.  Checking in.  Probably at work.  Anyways, I'll see you tomorrow night.  Love you.

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: I thought it'd be nicer to eat here.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Sounds good.

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: I'm sorry Sam couldn't make it.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah, those grad school applications are driving her crazy.

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: I'm sure everything'll work out.  She really loves you...

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: So how are things at the hospital?

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: Fine.  You know Dr. Schwartz retired last month?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: No kidd'n, he musta been pushing 90!

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: Close.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: So how'd you like LION KING?

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: Oh, I loved it.  I wish you'd gone.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I know.  I'm sorry.  Work.

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: You work too hard, John.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Look who's talking.

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: Hey, future boy.  Frank tells me you're a cop?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah, that's right.

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: My six year-old here keeps telling me he wants to be a policeman.  Right after he retires from the majors.  We just gave him a badge and a whistle for his birthday.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah...I remember.  I used to play cops and robbers but y-- ...my mom wouldn't let me have a toy gun.

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: You're mom sounds like she's got some smarts.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: She's pretty special.

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: Are you a good cop, John?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I try to be.

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: Then I'll bet she's real proud of you, huh?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah.  I just wish I'd told her how proud I was of her.

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: I'm sorry.  I didn't realize...  But she knew, John.  A mother knows what's in her son's heart.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Just came by to wrap up over there. Thought I'd say "hello."

turns.speaker: SHEPARD
turns.text: Glad you did.  Come on in.  Buy you a cup of coffee?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Wife around?

turns.speaker: SHEPARD
turns.text: No.  No.  Well, sort of.  In my heart. Been dead 29 years.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Oh.  Sorry.  How so?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You used to be on the job?

turns.speaker: SHEPARD
turns.text: Yeah, long time ago.  I know you?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I look familiar?

turns.speaker: SHEPARD
turns.text: No.  What house you work?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: The 2-3.  Homicide.

turns.speaker: SHEPARD
turns.text: A hot shot, huh?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Nah, just working the job.

turns.speaker: SHEPARD
turns.text: I hear that.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: As a matter of fact, I caught a case that goes back to your day...one of the Nightingale murders.

turns.speaker: SHEPARD
turns.text: No kiddin'?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: No.  Missing teenager.  Disappeared thirty years ago.  Found her bones last week.  Buried behind some old diner, up by Dyckman street.  Mary Finelli.

turns.speaker: SHEPARD
turns.text: Huh.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Talk about dumb luck.  Odds of anybody finding that girl, thirty years later. And then the chances of hitting a dental...forget about it.  Bets part is she's the first victim.  She knew the doer.  I'm betting those bones are gonna do a lot of talking.

turns.speaker: SHEPARD
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I'm the train wreck you didn't see coming.  And I'm gonna steal your life away.  You went down 30 years ago.  You just don't know it yet.

turns.speaker: SHEPARD
turns.text: Hell-

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You have the right to remain silent.  If you give up that right...

turns.speaker: SHEPARD
turns.text: Who the fuck is this?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Anything you say can and will be used against you in a court of law.

turns.speaker: SHEPARD
turns.text: Sullivan?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You have the right to speak to an att --

turns.speaker: SHEPARD
turns.text: Fuck you, asshole.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: It's a small world, Carl.  And I'm gonna find you.  Real soon.

turns.speaker: ABEL
turns.text: My name is Abel.  And I am my brother's keeper.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Where are you going?

turns.speaker: ABEL
turns.text: Going?  How do you mean?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I mean, is there any place in particular where we can drop you off?

turns.speaker: ABEL
turns.text: Drop me off?  How do you mean?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: What is that?

turns.speaker: ABEL
turns.text: I found this today.  There were other pieces of the body lying there, but I believe "he" wanted me to have this...

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: That's an eyeball!  Oh, God!

turns.speaker: ABEL
turns.text: "He" wanted me to warn you.  Look at this, all of you!

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Dammit Shelly!  Why do you always have to be such an asshole!

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I beg your pardon, I'm not an asshole.  I'm an actor.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Same thing.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Look Shelly, you're my roommate and I like you... most of the time.  But you gotta stop doing these things.  Now, I set this date up for you, didn't I?  So don't embarrass me.  When you meet this woman, just relax and be yourself.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Would you be yourself...  ...if you looked this this?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: No more... I can't!

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Yes, you can.  Come on, Shelly!

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Who brought up this bright idea?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: We were looking for something to keep our hands busy.  It was either this or an orgy.  Vera chose this.  What're ya gonna do?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: ... One thousand twelve... one thousand thirteen... one thousand fourteen... What's the World's Record for this?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: According to the Guinness Book, you passed the World's Record several whacks ago.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I did?!  I broke the world's record.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: You're all just jealous.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Actually, I have no idea what the World's Record is.  I was just kidding.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: What're you gonna do?

turns.speaker: DEBBIE
turns.text: Maybe this wasn't such a good idea.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: So what would a weekend in the country be without sex?

turns.speaker: DEBBIE
turns.text: Cool it, Andy.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I didn't mean it the way it sounded...

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Breakfast?

turns.speaker: DEBBIE
turns.text: No way.  We're pregnant.  Remember?

turns.speaker: DEBBIE
turns.text: What was that?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Where's Shelly?

turns.speaker: DEBBIE
turns.text: Why don't we go take a swim?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I don't know...

turns.speaker: DEBBIE
turns.text: We'd be all alone.  We could do anything we wanted and nobody would see.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Sounds disgusting.  Let's go.

turns.speaker: DEBBIE
turns.text: What're you doing?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: We haven't looked in the barn, yet.  Let's take a look.

turns.speaker: DEBBIE
turns.text: Not now.  I'm cold.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: How about a roll in the hay?

turns.speaker: DEBBIE
turns.text: You can play with yourself, 'cause I'm going in the house.

turns.speaker: DEBBIE
turns.text: How about you and I whacking a couple of balls around?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: If you insist.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: How do we do it?

turns.speaker: DEBBIE
turns.text: First we take off our clothes, then you get on top of me or I get on top of you...

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I know how to do it.  I mean, how do we do it in the hammock?

turns.speaker: DEBBIE
turns.text: Think you can figure it out?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I'll think of something.

turns.speaker: DEBBIE
turns.text: That was the best yet.  Was it you... me... or the hammock?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I vote for me.

turns.speaker: DEBBIE
turns.text: I vote for the hammock.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: What're you doin'?

turns.speaker: DEBBIE
turns.text: I think it's called "a shower". You might try it sometime.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: You're too clean for me.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Hey Deb... can you hear me?

turns.speaker: DEBBIE
turns.text: Barely.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I'm going downstairs to get a beer. You want one?

turns.speaker: DEBBIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Do you want a beer or not?

turns.speaker: DEBBIE
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Destroy the evidence?  No, man!

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Yes, man!

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: I'm gonna be sicker than all of you, man.  Now I gotta spend the whole weekend totally straight...  I don't think I can make it, man!

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Chuck... look.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: I'm a slow eater.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: I love you, man!

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: It's dark down there.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: That's the way it is, man. Cellars are dark.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: And Hell is hot, but I ain't goin' down there either.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Maybe we should do some exercise.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: This is all the exercise I need...

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: I can't find the bong anywhere. Can't you remember where you dropped it?

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: I can't even remember what day it is, man.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: It's Friday the 13th.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: What's the matter?!

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Nothin'.  I was just foolin' around.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Don't do that to me!

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Here.  Go down the cellar and check the fusebox.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Will you come with me?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Be a man, man.

turns.speaker: DEBBIE
turns.text: Which one is it?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: It's the last house on the left. She lives downstairs.
